fr:title.text: Kan fibration is trivial iff it is a weak equivalence

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kan fibration is trivial iff it is a weak equivalence

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Kan fibration is a trivial fibration iff it is a weak equivalence of simplicial sets.

Let f : X \to Y be a Kan fibration. In one direction, if f is a trivial fibration, it has a section f \mathbin {\circ } s = \textrm {id}, such that s \mathbin {\circ } f is homotopic to the identity (see Theorem ). This induces a bijection between connected components of Z^X and Z^Y.

In the other direction, notice that if X and Y themselves are Kan, then by Yoneda a map between them is a homotopy equivalence iff it is a weak equivalence. If the map is furthermore a fibration, then by Theorem it is a trivial fibration. Hence, we attempt to use this by taking a fibrant replacement Y \hookrightarrow \bar {Y} such that the inclusion map is anodyne. We need to extend the fibration along this inclusion, but this is difficult because fibrations can be very diverse. One option is to use the theory of minimal fibrations. They are locally product projections, which are much easier to extend.

Use Theorem to obtain a strong deformation retract X' \subseteq X relative to X such that f' : X' \to Y is a minimal Kan fibration. A strong deformation retract is a homotopy equivalence, which is a weak equivalence. By the two-out-of-three for weak equivalences, f' is a weak equivalence. We know f' is a Kan fiber bundle by Theorem , and we can attempt to extend this to \bar {Y}, which naturally motivates us to prove Theorem . This leads to a pullback square of Kan fiber bundles:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Use the first part of Theorem to conclude that the top and bottom anodyne maps are weak equivalences. By two-out-of-three, the right map is a weak equivalence. From the observation above, this means the right map is a trivial fibration, since \bar {Y} is Kan. We can now conclude that the left map is a trivial fibration, and in particular a homotopy equivalence. Since X' \to X is also a homotopy equivalence, by two-out-of-three we see X \to Y is a homotopy equivalence, which means it is a trivial fibration by Theorem .

fr:title.text: cofibration is trivial iff it is a weak equivalence

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: cofibration is trivial iff it is a weak equivalence

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A cofibration (monomorphism) is a trivial cofibration (anodyne map) iff it is a weak equivalence of simplicial sets.

By the Joyal–Tierney calculus on product and exponentials, given an anodyne map i : X \to Y and a Kan complex Z, the map Z^Y \to Z^X is a trivial fibration. This means it is a bijection on connected components, and hence i is a weak equivalence.

On the other hand, if i is a weak equivalence, we factor it as a trivial cofibration j : X \to Z composed with a Kan fibration p : Z \to Y. By two-out-of-three and the previous part of the proof, p must be a weak equivalence. By Theorem , p is a trivial Kan fibration. Therefore i left lifts against p, this produces a diagram:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} X & Y \\ Z & Z \arrow ["j", from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow ["i"', from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow ["p", from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow [dashed, from=2-1, to=1-2] \arrow [equals, from=2-1, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can now retract p away from i = p \mathbin {\circ } j, to express i as a retract of j. Since trivial cofibrations are closed under retracts, i is also a trivial cofibration.

fr:title.text: Kan fibration is a homotopy equivalence iff it is trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kan fibration is a homotopy equivalence iff it is trivial

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Kan fibration is a homotopy equivalence iff it is a trivial fibration.

In one direction, suppose we have a trivial fibration f : X \to Y. Consider the monomorphism \textrm {id} : X \to X. The lifting property for the obvious square gives a section s : Y \to X, i.e. f \mathbin {\circ } s = \textrm {id}. Now consider this lifting problem:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} {\{0,1\} \times X} & X \\ {\Delta ^1 \times X} & Y \arrow ["{\langle \textrm {id}, s \mathbin {\circ } f \rangle }", from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow [hook, from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow ["f", from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow [dashed, from=2-1, to=1-2] \arrow [from=2-1, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This provides a homotopy from s \mathbin {\circ } f to \textrm {id}. In particular f is a homotopy equivalence. We can improve this even further: since s provides an embedding of Y into X, we can change the top-left corner to (\{0, 1\} \times X) \cup (\Delta ^1 \times Y), since s \mathbin {\circ } f is equal to the identity there. This exhibites Y as a strong deformation retract of X.

On the other hand, if f is a fibration and a homotopy equivalence, we can proceed in the opposite direction, and we first improve it to a deformation retract. The following lifting problem replaces s with s' such that fs' equals \textrm {id} on the nose.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} Y & X \\ {\Delta ^1 \times Y} & Y \arrow ["s", from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow ["0"', from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow ["f", from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow ["{s \sim s'}"{description}, dashed, from=2-1, to=1-2] \arrow ["{fs \sim \textrm {id}}"', from=2-1, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Now we further improve the homotopy equivalence into a strong deformation retract. This time we can’t use (\{0, 1\} \times X) \cup (\Delta ^1 \times Y) as the top-left corner since we don't have trivial fibrancy yet, but we know there exists a homotopy s' f \sim \textrm {id}, so we can exploit this to use (\Lambda ^2_1 \times X) \cup (\Delta ^2 \times Y) \hookrightarrow \Delta ^2 \times X, where the top map goes from \textrm {id} to s' f back to \textrm {id} on the X part, and the Y part is given by the triangle witnessing the composition of inverses cancel.

Finally, given a strong deformation retract, we can lift along any map A \to B by composition with the section s', but then the upper triangle only commute up to homotopy. Now (here we use A \to B being mono) we can construct a lifting problem against the anodyne map (\{0\} \times B) \cup (\Delta ^1 \times A) \hookrightarrow \Delta ^1 \times A to make a strict lifting.

fr:title.text: cofibration is trivial iff it is a weak equivalence

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: cofibration is trivial iff it is a weak equivalence

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A cofibration (monomorphism) is a trivial cofibration (anodyne map) iff it is a weak equivalence of simplicial sets.

By the Joyal–Tierney calculus on product and exponentials, given an anodyne map i : X \to Y and a Kan complex Z, the map Z^Y \to Z^X is a trivial fibration. This means it is a bijection on connected components, and hence i is a weak equivalence.

On the other hand, if i is a weak equivalence, we factor it as a trivial cofibration j : X \to Z composed with a Kan fibration p : Z \to Y. By two-out-of-three and the previous part of the proof, p must be a weak equivalence. By Theorem , p is a trivial Kan fibration. Therefore i left lifts against p, this produces a diagram:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

\begin {tikzcd} X & Y \\ Z & Z \arrow ["j", from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow ["i"', from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow ["p", from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow [dashed, from=2-1, to=1-2] \arrow [equals, from=2-1, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can now retract p away from i = p \mathbin {\circ } j, to express i as a retract of j. Since trivial cofibrations are closed under retracts, i is also a trivial cofibration.
Given a Kan fibration f : X \to Y, there is a subset X' \subseteq X, being a strong deformation retract relative to f, such that X' \to Y is a minimal Kan fibration.

Notice that among degenerate simplices, the minimality condition is already satisfied, because degenerate simplices are determined by their boundaries. To construct X', we proceed by dimension. First take the homotopy equivalence classes of simplices of X whose boundaries lie in X', and if a class contains a degenerate simplex, pick one as a representative, otherwise pick any. Let these representatives be in X'. Notice that all the degenerate simplices from earlier dimensions are all picked by the observation earlier.

Now we construct a strong deformation retract, i.e. a homotopy \Delta ^1 \times X \to X, such that the restriction to \Delta ^1 \times X' is the projection map, the restruction to \{0\} \times X is also the projection map, and composition with f produces a constant homotopy. We also proceed by levels. For each level, we have an open prism in \Delta ^1 \times \Delta ^n, which we can fill since this subset is anodyne, and then we can compose with a homotopy relative to the boundaries to get into X'.

fr:title.text: extension of minimal fibrations along anodyne maps

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: extension of minimal fibrations along anodyne maps

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given a minimal fibration p : E \to X and an anodyne map i : X \to X', we can extend the fibration to p' : E' \to X', such that p is the pullback of p' along i, and i' : E \to E' is also an anodyne map.

We prove that we can do this for all horn inclusions, and then prove the class of such maps is a saturated cofibration class. For horn inclusions, a high-brow way to see this is to use the simplicial group \mathrm {Aut}(F) \subseteq F^F where F is the fiber, and \mathrm {Aut} takes the simplicial subset spanned by the isomorphisms. We see that a simplicial fiber bundle is essentially described by a map into the classifying space defined by the W-bar construction. In any case, a minimal fibration over a horn is isomorphic to a product projection, and therefore \Delta ^n \times F \to \Delta ^n obviously qualifies as an extension. We note that anodyne maps are closed under product with other simplicial sets.

Saturation is mostly straightforward, except pushouts. The obvious solution for pushouts requires us to verify this variant of Mather cube theorem in the category of simplicial sets (and hence sets): if there are cartesian morphisms of maps f_1 \leftarrow f \rightarrow f_2, then taking pushouts we have f_1 \to g \leftarrow f_2. If f \to f_1 is injective, then f_1 \to g \leftarrow f_2 is also cartesian. This is known as adhesiveness.

Given a Kan fibration f : X \to Y, it is minimal if for all n-simplices a, b in X such that \partial a = \partial b and f(a) = f(b), they are one-step homotopic relative to f (i.e. there is a map from \Delta ^1 \times \Delta ^n with endpoints a and b such that composing with f gives a constant homotopy) iff they are already equal.

fr:title.text: minimal fibration is locally a product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: minimal fibration is locally a product

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A minimal Kan fibration f : X \to Y restricted to a simplex is isomorphic to a product projection \Delta ^n \times F \to \Delta ^n, i.e. it is a Kan fiber bundle.

Consider the strong deformation retract from \Delta ^n to the zeroth vertex. We can pull f back along this homotopy to get a minimal fibration X' \to \Delta ^n \times \Delta ^1, such that over \Delta ^n \times \{1\} the fibration is a product where F is the preimage of the zeroth vertex. Now using the Kan condition we can construct a homotopy equivalence between the fibration over \Delta ^n \times \{0\} and \Delta ^n \times \{1\}, but by Theorem this gives an isomorphism between the minimal fibration and a product.

A trivial fibration of simplicial sets is a map that right lifts against all simplex boundary inclusions \partial \Delta ^n \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n. A cofibration is a map that left lifts against all trivial fibrations. A cofibration is exactly a monomorphism.

Using the small object argument, a trivial cofibration is the smallest \omega -saturated cofibration class containing simplex boundary inclusions. Monomorphisms form such a class, and so a trivial cofibration is a monomorphism. For the other direction, we prove that every monomorphism can be obtained by \omega -saturation. We first note that any subset X \subseteq \Delta ^n is a trivial fibration by inductively dropping faces from \Delta ^n \subseteq \Delta ^n: if we want to drop a k-dimensional face, perform a cobase change of \partial \Delta ^k \hookrightarrow \Delta ^k and compose it with the current subset inclusion.

Given a simplicial subset X \subseteq Y, we construct a tower of inclusions X \subseteq Z_0 \subseteq Z_1 \subseteq \cdots \subseteq Y, where Z_n is the union of X with the n-skeleton of Y, considered as simplicial subsets of Y. We just need to prove each inclusion is a trivial cofibration. For X \subseteq Z_0, simply take the coproduct with a bunch of \varnothing = \partial \Delta ^0 \subseteq \Delta ^0. For Z_{n-1} \subseteq Z_{n}, take the coproduct of a bunch of \partial \Delta ^n \subseteq \Delta ^n, and perform a cobase change to glue them onto Z_{n-1}.

Constructively, this argument requires us to decide whether a simplex is in the subset, and if so determine whether it is non-degerate (otherwise we do not want to take a copy of that simplex in the coproduct).
Given a map f : X \to Y between simplicial sets, it is a weak equivalence if \hom (Y, K) \to \hom (X, K) induces a bijection on connected components for all Kan complexes.

Suppose a map f of simplicial sets has the right lifting property against all inner horn inclusions \Lambda ^n_i \hookrightarrow \Delta ^n, where n \ge 1 and 0 < i < n, then we say f is an inner fibration. If we strengthen the condition to 0 \le i < n, then we get the left fibration. Similarly for right fibrations. If we allow 0 \le i \le n, then we get a Kan fibration. Hence, an \infty -category is the same as an inner fibration X \to 1. The same goes for a Kan complex.

The class of maps that have left lifting property against all inner fibrations is called inner anodyne. Similarly for left and right anodyne maps. For Kan fibrations, we use the unqualified phrase “anodyne map”. Obviously we have inner anodyne maps contained in both left and right anodyne maps, which in turn are contained in anodyne maps. They are all monomorphisms.

Given a simplicial fiber bundle p : E \to B, it is a Kan fibration iff the fiber F is a Kan complex. Hence we call it a Kan fiber bundle. The proof yields an effective Kan fibration if all the inputs are effective.

Given a horn \Lambda ^n_k \to E and a compatible simplex \Delta ^n \to B, by the definition of simplicial fiber bundles, we may trivialize the bundle on the simplex locally. But since F is Kan, obviously F \times \Delta ^n \to \Delta ^n is also Kan. Hence we may select the required filling.
